questions.text: A truck driver presents with a painless, circumscribed ulcer over the penis. He had unprotected sexual intercourse two weeks ago. Examination reveals a non-tender ulcer with an indurated base. Exudate shows the following picture on microscopy. What type of motility is exhibited by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative agent is Treponema pallidum, which exhibits corkscrew motility.

The clinical vignette of a painless, non-tender, circumscribed ulcer over the penis with an indurated base that developed subsequent to unprotected sexual intercourse, and the finding on darkfield microscopy are suggestive of primary syphilis.

It is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete that is actively motile. The motility is best observed on dark ground or phase-contrast microscopy.

The movement is described as corkscrew-like with the organism moving backward and forward while rotating around the long axis. In addition, secondary curves are observed to appear and disappear, as the organism moves.

Primary syphilis occurs subsequent to inoculation of treponema pallidum following sexual contact. It manifests as a local, nontender ulcer over the genitalia called a hard chancre, in 2-10 weeks. 

It can be diagnosed using VDRL, RPR test and can be confirmed by FTA – ABS testing or TPHA, TPI testing.

The bacteria can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. Smear specimens are stained using Fontana stain and pathological tissues are stained using Levaditi stain. Silver impregnation technique can also be used. 

Other options : 

Option B: Darting motility is exhibited by Vibrio cholerae. It is the causative agent of cholera, an acute diarrheal disease characterized by vomiting and stool that is colorless and watery called 'rice water stool'.

Option C: Gliding motility is exhibited by Mycoplasma. It can cause primary atypical pneumonia and genital infections in humans.

Option D: Tumbling motility is exhibited by Listeria monocytogenes. It is the causative agent of listeriosis, which can manifest as meningitis or sepsis in neonates, meningoencephalitis in the elderly, and immunocompromised.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of sore throat and low grade fever. Examination reveals cervical lymphadenopathy and grey white discharge-covered tonsils. Gram staining showed the following appearance. Choose the incorrect statement regarding the causative bacteria.

choices.text: Albert stain is used for diagnosis
The toxin acts via ADP ribosylation of EF-2
Iron level regulate the production of toxin

questions.solution:
A child presenting with a sore throat, cervical lymphadenopathy, grey-white discharged covered tonsils and gram stain showing gram-positive rods with clubbed ends, beaded appearance, and Chinese-letter pattern of arrangement is suggestive of diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheria is not chromosome encoded, it is phage-encoded (tox gene). 

Albert’s stain or Neisser’s stain or Loeffler's methylene blue are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules of Corynebacterium diphtheria. These granules are called polar bodies as they are situated at the ends of the bacilli. The organism can be cultured in Loeffler's serum slope and Tellurite blood agar.

The image below demonstrates C. diphtheriae in Albert's stain as green bacilli with purple-blue metachromatic granules.

The systemic manifestations of diphtheria are due to diphtheria toxin. It is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments - A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding the toxin to the cells while fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) by ADP ribosylation responsible for protein synthesis and the iron level regulates the toxin production.

The clinical manifestation of diphtheria depends on the site of infection. Pharyngeal/faucial diphtheria is the most common presentation. The patient has marked adenitis and a bull neck. Pseudomembrane over the tonsils is characteristic. Bleeding from the tonsils can occur. It leads to life-threatening complications such as asphyxia, circulatory failure, post-diphtheritic paralysis, and toxaemia.

Cutaneous diphtheria may manifest as diphtheritic whitlow or skin ulcer.

The image below shows the pseudomembrane over the tonsil typically seen in diphtheria.

Image below shows bull neck.

Treatment of diphtheria consist of administering diphtheria anti-toxin (20,000 - 100,000 units) and supplementing with antibiotics (penicillin and erythromycin).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes with multiple circular, dry, scaly, itchy lesions on the scalp.  On further examination, it is seen that hair is involved but nails are spared. Scrapings from the lesion are inoculated and examined microscopically. Identify the dermatophyte based on the macroconidia seen in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of tinea capitis and the image showing large spindle-shaped macroconidia is a feature of Microsporum.

Dermatophytosis (commonly called tinea or ringworm) refers to infection of keratinized structures (the skin, hair, and nails) caused by a group of keratinophilic fungi, called the dermatophytes.

Dermatophytes are classified into 3 types:

  • Trichophyton infects skin, hair, and nails. The species include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc. Microconidia > Macroconidia
  • Microsporum infects only hair and skin but, not the nails. The species include M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. Macroconidia> Microconidia.
  • Epidermophyton infects only skin and nails, not hair. Floccosum is the only species in this genus. Only Macroconidia.

Clinical features of infection by Microsporum include:

  • Skin lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.
  • Hair lesions include kerion, scarring, and alopecia.

Diagnosis is established by clinical features, the use of Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as microscopic examination and culture characteristics.

Microscopic examination of material teased out from the fungal colony (culture mount) or material taken on cellotape (cellotape mount) is observed for identification of the species. It is observed for the presence and type of hyphae and conidia. Conidia (asexual spores) are of two types: small unicellular microconidia and larger septate macroconidia.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with severe headache, photophobia and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilledema and nuchal rigidity was present. Kernig's and Brudzinski signs were positive.  CSF examination shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. Causative organism is:
questions.solution:
History, physical examination, and CSF findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis. The given image shows intracellular Gram-negative diplococci i.e. Neisseria meningitidis.

The genus Neisseria consists of Gram-negative, aerobic, non-sporulating, non-motile, oxidase-positive cocci arranged typically in pairs (diplococci). It includes two pathogens: Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The important difference is the presence of a polysaccharide capsule in N meningitidis.

The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx. From the nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteremia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection. Clinical features include fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Kernig's sign, Brudzinski's signs). Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash due to petechial hemorrhages.

Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

The selective medium used is the Modified Thayer-Martin medium (with vancomycin, colistin, and nystatin). The colonies are seen as small, translucent, convex, bluish-grey, with a smooth glistening surface and lenticular in shape on solid media.

Intravenous penicillin G is the treatment of choice. Eradicative therapy is to be given with rifampicin or ciprofloxacin to prevent the carrier state.

Chemoprophylaxis is indicated for the household and close contacts. The preferred antibiotics are rifampin, ciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone. Monovalent, polyvalent, and conjugate vaccines are available.

Other options:

Option A: Haemophilus influenzae type B is a gram-negative bacillus with considerable polymorphism. In sputum, clusters of coccobacillary forms are seen; In CSF, long bacillary filamentous forms predominate. H. influenzae b grows on chocolate agar (which supplies necessary nutrients from lysed red blood cells) or on blood agar (appear as satellite colonies surrounding β-hemolytic colonies of S. aureus).

Option C: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram positive, capsulated, flame shaped or lanceolate shaped diplococci. In culture, the typical morphology may not be apparent and the cocci are more rounded, tending to occurjp short chain

Option D: Listeria monocytogenes is a short, non sporing, gram positive bacillus. It shows characteristic tumbling motility at 25°C, but is non motile at 37°C.

questions.text: A child presents with profuse, painless diarrhea. Stool microscopy shows the following finding. What is this characteristic appearance called?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of cholera caused by Vibrio cholerae.  The image shows the characteristic fish in stream appearance of Vibrio.

Other options:

Options A and B: School of fish appearance and railroad appearance are shown by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Option D: Drumstick appearance is shown by Clostridium tetani due to its spherical and terminal spores.

questions.text: Identify the fungus shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The image above shows the fungus Cryptococcus, stained with India ink.

The India ink preparation is employed to detect the presence of Cryptococcus neoformans. Direct microscopy of the sample stained by India ink is the most rapid method for the diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis. It is seen as a globular, encapsulated yeast cell with or without budding, between 5 to 20 μm in diameter in size. Cryptococcus has a polysaccharide capsule which is seen against a black background.

Indian ink is a negative staining method that provides a uniformly colored background. The unstained organisms stand out in contrast to the background. It is useful in the demonstration of organisms with capsules that do not take simple stains. It is also used to stain slender bacteria like spirochetes.

Cryptococcus can be cultured from biologic samples like the CSF, sputum, and skin biopsy on routine fungal and bacterial culture media. Colonies are opaque, white-to-cream colored, and may turn orange-tan or brown after prolonged incubation. They have a mucoid appearance due to the presence of the capsule around the yeast cells.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fever, joint pain, and urticarial rash. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. Laboratory test reveals eosinophilia. Stool sample microscopy image is given below. Which of the following organism is responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing a non-operculated egg with a lateral spine near the rounded posterior end is suggestive of Katayama fever caused by Schistosoma mansoni. 

Adult worms of S. mansoni live in the inferior mesenteric vein and their infective form is fork-tailed cercaria.

Following skin penetration by cercariae, a pruritic rash termed cercarial dermatitis or swimmers itch develops locally which is self-limiting.

After 4- 8 weeks of the cercarial invasion, high worm load, and egg antigen stimuli lead to the formation of immune complexes which result in a serum sickness-like illness termed Katayama fever. They present with high-grade fever, rash, arthralgia, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and eosinophilia. Katayama fever can also be caused by  Schistosoma japonicum, but the disease is more severe in S.japanicum due to higher egg production. 

When eggs get deposited in the small intestine, patients develop abdominal pain and blood dysentery for a long time called intestinal bilharziasis. The eggs deposited in the intestinal wall lead to microabscesses, granulomas, hyperplasia, and fibrosis. 

 

The drug of choice is praziquantel 40mg/kg single oral dose. Oxamniquine 15mg/kg single oral dose is also an effective dose. 

Note:- Praziquantel is the drug of choice for all trematodes except Fasciola hepatica and Fasciola gigantica. Triclabendazole is the drug of choice for these.

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given slide stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain.
questions.solution:
The given slide stained with GMS shows acute-angled (45o) uniform, branching septate hyphae which is suggestive of Aspergillus species.

Aspergillus species grow rapidly, producing aerial hyphae that bear conidia in chains. Long aseptate conidiophores (specialised conidia-bearing hyphae) are seen with terminal vesicles. Phialides (vase-shaped cells producing conidia) with conidia are arranged in basipetal chains on the terminal vesicle. The following image shows the lactophenol cotton blue solution (LPCB) mount of Aspergillus fumigatus showing the long conidiophores with terminal vesicles.

Option A: Mucor produces nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium.

Option B: Penicillium produces septate hyphae with branched, septate and brush-like conidiophores.

Option D: Rhizopus appears similar to Mucor but it has rhizoids with sporangiophores arising in groups directly above the rhizoids.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: Histology under KOH preparation showed the following bodies. This is seen in case of _________
questions.solution:
The image shows medlar bodies which are seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Histologically on potassium hydroxide preparation, the lesions show the presence of the fungus as round, irregular, dark brown, yeast like bodies with septae called sclerotic bodies/ medlar bodies/ copper penny bodies. These structures multiply by septation, and they induce a purulent and granulomatous inflammatory reaction in tissue.

Chromoblastomycosis is the most common form of chromomycosis, which is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and the subcutaneous tissue caused by dematiaceous (pigmented) fungi.

The M/C fungi responsible are species of the genera Fonsecaea (Fonsecaea pedrosoi or Fonsecaea compacta).

questions.text: A patient from Kolar, Karnataka presented with fever and hemoptysis. The findings of his peripheral smear examination are given below. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario and the image showing the characteristic "safety-pin appearance" in peripheral smear is suggestive of plague caused by Yersinia pestis.

On staining with Giemsa stain or methylene blue (Wayson's stain), the bacteria has bipolar staining with two ends densely stained and the central area clear. This is the characteristic 'safety-pin appearance' seen in Y. pestis.

Bipolar staining is also shown by the following organisms:

  • Haemophilus ducreyi
  • Vibrio parahemolyticus
  • Calymmatobacterium granulomatis
  • Burkholderia mallei
  • Burkholderia pseudomallei.

Note: In India, 4 foci of plague are known:

  • Kolar at the trijunction of Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, and Karnataka.
  • Beed-Latur belt in Maharashtra
  • Rhoru, Himachal Pradesh 
  • Uttarakhand

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The microscopic image shows typical brush-like conidiophores seen in Penicillium species.

Microscopic appearance of Penicillium spp.:

  • The hyphae are hyaline and septate.
  • They produce characteristic brush-like conidiophores.
  •  The conidiophore is the stalk-like structure, which bears structures known as metulae from which flask-shaped phialides produce chains of asexual spores known as conidia.

Other options:

Option A: Aspergillus spp. has conidiophores with swollen rounded ends (vesicles) which bear the sterigmata, from which the conidia arise.

Option B: Fusarium spp. on lactophenol cotton blue stain shows small septate hyphae and produces phialides, which give rise to single-celled microconidia or large multi-cell sickle or fusiform-shaped macroconidia, as shown in the image below.

Option D: Scopulariopsis spp. causes onychomycosis, pulmonary infection, fungus ball, and invasive fungal disease in immunocompromised hosts. Microscopically, conidia are large, spherical, lemon-shaped, arranged in chains.

questions.text: A 45 -year-old HIV-positive patient has patchy pneumonia.  Smears of induced sputum and sedimented cells from lavage fluid stained with methenamine silver are as seen below. Which is the most likely organism implicated?
questions.solution:
The smears stained with methenamine silver show black-colored stained cysts resembling the crushed ping pong balls of Pneumocystis jirovecii.

Approximately 15% to 30% of untreated HIV-infected people develop pneumonia during the course of the disease. It is mainly caused by the fungus P. jirovecii (reactivation of prior latent infection).

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: A 20-year-old man from West Bengal presents with recurrent fever with chills for the past 3 months with progressive weakness and abdominal discomfort. On examination, he has hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow aspiration finding is shown in the image below. Which of the following skin tests can be used to know the prior exposure to this parasite?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 20-year-old man presenting with fever with chills, progressive weakness, and abdominal discomfort for the past 3 months and the bone marrow aspirate showing Leishman-Donovan bodies are suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis. A positive Montenegro skin test indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasite.

Leishmaniasis is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of the genus Leishmania. It is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly, which inoculates the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host in developing countries. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.

Causative organisms include:

  • Old world leishmaniasis: Leishmania donovani, Leishmania major, and Leishmania tropica
  • New world leishmaniasis: Leishmania mexicana complex and Leishmania braziliensis complex

The image given below shows a phlebotomus sandfly.

The image below shows Lutzomyia sandfly responsible for the New World cutaneous leishmanisis.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestations:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis/ kala-azar
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis
  • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms:

  • The promastigote develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and
  • The amastigote multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.  

When the infected sandfly bites a person, infectious promastigotes are released into the host dermis along with the sandfly's saliva, which potentiates parasite infectivity. Amastigote form (as shown in the image below) is also known as the Leishman-Donovan (LD) body. It is an intracellular form found inside macrophages, monocytes, and reticuloendothelial cells. It contains a kinetoplast, which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum is absent.

Promastigote form (as shown in the below image) is present in the midgut of the female sandfly. The kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end. A single flagellum is seen. It is the infective form of L. donovani for humans.

Given below is the lifecycle of L. donovanii.

This condition causes fever with rigor and chills associated with splenomegaly and hepatomegaly. It lowers immunity and causes persistent fever, anaemia, leucopenia, and thrombocytopenia, if left untreated, death may occur due to opportunistic infection.

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

The image below shows amastigotes located intracellularly within macrophages.

Tests to detect leishmaniasis include:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 Rapid diagnostic test and Kala-azar dipstick test strip. This is recommended by the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) in India.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear - confirmatory.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescent antibody test
  • Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: A skin test, 0.1 ml of killed promastigote suspension is injected intradermally on the dorsoventral aspect of foremarmInduration of 5mm or more is considered positive and indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasite. In active kala azar, this test is negative and becomes positive after 6-8 weeks (delayed hypersensitivity) after a cure from the disease or if the patient developed protective immunity.

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are

  • Sodium stibogluconate - Drug of choice in countries where strains are sensitive to antimony compounds.
  • Miltefosine - Alternative to sodium stibogluconate and only oral drug used in Kala-azar.
  • Amphotericin B - Drug of choice in India, as 40-60% of strains are resistant to antimony compounds. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10 mg/kg IV is the first line of treatment in India, 

Other options:  

Option A: Frenkel's test is done in toxoplasmosis.

Option C: Fairley's test is done in schistosomiasis.

Option D: Bachman intradermal test done in trichinellosis.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

Related Pearl: Various morphological stages of hemoflagellates

It is based on the arrangement of the flagella in relation to the position of the nucleus and its point of emergence from the cells.

Stage Morphological characteristics Seen in
Amastigote

Rounded or ovoid, without any external flagellum.

The nucleus, kinetoplast, and axial filaments can be seen.

The axoneme extends up to the anterior end of the cell

Promastigote

Lanceolate in shape.

Antenuclear kinetoplast- kinetoplast is anterior to the nucleus near the anterior end of the cell, from which flagellum emerges.

There is no undulating membrane

 It is the infective stage of Leishmania, found in the insect vector as well as in cultures in­vitro.
Epimastigote

Elongated.

The flagellum runs alongside the body as a short undulating membrane, before emerging from the anterior end.

It is the form in which Trypanosoma brucei occurs in the salivary gland of the vector tsetse fly and Trypanosoma cruzi in the midgut of the vector reduviid bug.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

This stage is elongated, spindle-shaped with a central nucleus.

Postnuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus and situated at the posterior end of the body.

The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end.

This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of an infected vertebrate.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

questions.text: The below given appearance is related to:
questions.solution:
In the given image, the black arrow points towards maltese cross, and yellow arrow points towards the ring form seen in Babesia.

Babesia, a genus of protozoan organisms that includes Babesia microti and Babesia duncani, are responsible for babesiosis. Ixodid ticks are the definitive host. Man is an intermediate host. Sporozoites are the infective form of humans.

The mode of infection is through a tick bite. Occasionally it can also be through blood transfusion.

The majority of the clinical symptoms are predominantly caused by hemolysis of the infected erythrocytes. The illness develops 1-6 weeks after the tick bite. It might be a mild, self-limiting, asymptomatic, or severe sickness that resembles malaria.
Malaise, exhaustion, high-grade fever (38°C to 40.6°C) with chills and sweating, myalgia, arthralgia, a dry cough, and anorexia are symptoms of acute illness.

Complications of acute babesiosis include renal failure, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and congestive cardiac failure (CCF).

On microscopic examination by Giemsa stain, Babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring form. The ring form is the most common and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit which differentiates it from P. falciparum. Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/Maltese crosses, which are pathognomonic of B. microti or B. duncani.

Treatment of B. microti infection

  • Mild infection is treated with atovaquone along with azithromycin
  • Severe infections are treated with azithromycin along with atovaquone or clindamycin along with quinine
  • Exchange transfusion is required in patients with high-grade parasitemia (≥10%), severe anaemia, and pulmonary, hepatic, or renal compromise.

Other Babesia infections are treated with a combination of clindamycin and quinine.

questions.text: You are a microbiology resident teaching the staining technique shown in the image below to medical students. What is the order of the steps to be followed in this technique?

choices.text: Crystal violet, iodine solution, decolorisation, carbol fuchsin
Crystal violet, decolorisation, iodine solution, carbol fuchsin
Carbol fuchsin, iodine solution, decolorisation, crystal violet
Crystal violet, carbol fuchsin, iodine solution, decolorisation

questions.solution:
The given microscopy image shows Gram staining, and the order of Gram staining is as follows:

  • Primary staining with para-rosaniline dye (crystal violet, methyl violet, or gentian violet)
  • Application of dilute iodine solution
  • Decolorisation with an organic solvent (ethanol, acetone, aniline)
  • Counterstaining with the dye of contrasting color (carbol fuchsin, safranine, neutral red)

The suggested theories in Gram staining are that a gram-positive organism retains the primary basic dye due to its acidic protoplasm. Also, a thick peptidoglycan layer present in gram-positive bacteria helps in retaining the dye-iodine complex. The lipid content in gram-negative bacteria is very high, which makes it permeable to secondary dye after decolorization with organic solvents like acetone.

Therefore, gram-positive bacteria retain the primary stain and appear violet. Gram-negative bacteria appear red because they get decolorized and take up the counterstain.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odor with a pH of  4.7. Microscopy reveals the cell shown in the below image. According to CDC guidelines, all the following could be used to treat this condition except?

choices.text: Metronidazole oral tablets 500 mg twice daily

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image showing a clue cell is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis and 5% clotrimazole vaginal cream is not used in the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. 

Bacterial vaginosis is associated with alteration in the normal vaginal flora. There is a decrease in lactobacilli with a 100-fold increase in the growth of other anaerobic bacteria namely Haemophilus vaginalis, Gardnerella, Mobiluncus, and Myco­plasma hominis.

The patient complains of vaginal discharge with a fishy odor. Microscopy shows characteristic clue cells, which are vaginal epithelial cells with margins obscured by microbes. These suggest a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis.

Amsel’s criteria are used in the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes:

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine-like odor(fishy odor) on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

At least three of the four criteria should be present to confirm the diagnosis.

The CDC recommends one of the following treatment regimens.

  • Tablet metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days
  • Clindamycin 2% cream 5 g intravaginally for 7 days
  • Metronidazole 0.75% gel 5 g intravaginally for 5 days

Other drugs that can be used include tinidazole and secnidazole.

questions.text: Identify the organism & the stain seen in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Helicobacter pylori stained using Warthin-Starry stain.

H.pylori is a Gram-negative spiral rod that is motile by a unipolar tuft of lophotrichous flagella. The bacteria are present only in the mucus overlying the gastric mucosa and do not actually invade into the mucosa.

The given image shows Helicobacter pylori on gastric mucosa stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain.

questions.text: Suspicious deaths were occurring after receiving parcels via mail in the USA. The microscopy of the specimen collected showed the following appearance. The bioterrorism agent involved can also show ___________
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a bioterrorism agent with the gram stain showing a box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance is suggestive of Bacillus anthracis (Category A bioterrorism agent). Bacillus anthracis can also show a medusa head appearance on microscopy.

Bacillus anthracis is a non-motile gram-positive bacillus that has a characteristic box car or a bamboo stick appearance on gram staining. On the agar plate, they form irregular round colonies that are raised, dull, greyish-white colonies giving a frosted glass appearance as given in the image below.

Long interlacing chains of bacilli, resembling matted hair, are present on the edge of the colonies giving it a medusa-head appearance when seen on low-power microscopy.

M’Fadyean’s reaction is used to demonstrate the polypeptide capsule which is stained with polychrome methylene blue. It also shows an inverted fir tree appearance on gelatin slab culture. On a solid media containing penicillin, the colonies give a string of pearls appearance as given in the image below. 

Other options:

Option A: A fried egg appearance of colonies is seen in the case of Mycoplasma.

Option C: Draughtsman or carrom coin appearance of colonies on blood agar is seen in the case of Streptococcus pneumonia, as given in the image below.

Option D: A fluorescent antibody-stained specimen of Yersinia pestis reveals rod-shaped bacteria with characteristic bipolar staining or safety pin or hairpin-like appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is a property of the cell wall of the organism that stains as shown below?

choices.text: Absence of aromatic and sulphur containing amino acids

questions.solution:
The given image shows Gram-negative bacilli, the cell walls of which contain lipopolysaccharides.

The table below gives a comparison of the cell walls of gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.

  Gram-positive Gram-negative
Teichoic acid, lipoteichoic acid Present Absent
Thickness (Peptidoglycan) Thicker Thinner
Variety of amino acids Few Several
Aromatic and sulphur-containing amino acids Absent Present
Lipopolysaccharides and outer membrane Absent Present

Lipopolysaccharides present on the cell walls of gram-negative bacteria account for the endotoxic activity and O antigen specificity. The outermost layer of the gram-negative bacterial cell wall is called the outer membrane and contains several proteins called outer membrane proteins. 

Gram-positive bacteria contain teichoic acid, which is a major surface antigen containing ribitol or glycerol polymers.

The procedure of Gram staining :

  1. Primary staining with a pararosaniline dye such as crystal violet, methyl violet, or gentian violet.
  2. Application of a dilute solution of iodine - fixes the primary dye by forming a crystal violet-iodine complex to prevent easy removal of dye.
  3. Decolourisation with an organic solvent such as ethanol, acetone, or aniline
  4. Counterstaining with a dye of contrasting colour, such as carbol fuchsin, safranine, or neutral red

The gram-positive cell wall is thicker with several layers of peptidoglycan, which helps retain the primary stain and hence appear violet. The gram-negative cell wall has more lipids, which are dissolved by the decolourising agents, causing rapid decolourisation and taking up the counterstain, hence appearing red.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who had recently been to the desert in the southwestern US presents with fever, cough, severe fatigue, symmetrical joint pain, and pleuritic chest pain.  On examination, erythema nodosum is noted. Tissue culture findings are as shown below. What is the most likely causative agent in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a flu-like illness, erythema nodosum, symmetrical joint pain, and pleuritic chest pain with a history of travel to south western USA and tissue culture showing spherules points toward the diagnosis of coccidioidomycosis and the causative agent is Coccidioides immitis.

Coccidioides immitis is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It occurs as a spherule in tissues and culture at 37°C and as the mycelial form in soil and culture at room temperature. They are endemic to the arid desert regions of the southwestern USA and California. Infection is acquired by inhaling dust containing arthrospores of the fungus.

The infection can be asymptomatic, or patients may present with symptoms like fever, cough, and pleuritic chest pain. It is also referred to as Valley fever. Some clinical features occur due to an immunologic response. These include toxic erythema, erythema nodosum, and erythema multiforme. Symmetrical arthralgias called desert rheumatism may also be seen. Clinical dissemination of infection outside the thoracic cavity occurs in immunocompromised patients. 

Diagnosis:- Sputum, bronchoalveolar lavage, and biopsy specimens are the samples used for diagnosis. Microscopy shows spherule with endospores. Culture on brain heart infusion agar with 5% blood shows white-coloured colonies and is the most specific for diagnosis. Serology using ELISA, Immunodiffusion assays, and complement fixation assays are also used to detect IgM and IgG antibodies. Delayed hypersensitivity can be demonstrated by a positive skin test with 'coccidiodin' (analogous to the tuberculin test).

Azole drugs such as fluconazole and itraconazole are the mainstay of treatment. Severe cases are managed with intravenous amphotericin B. 

Other options:

Option B: Paracoccidioidis brasiliensis causes paracoccidioidomycosis. It is a chronic ulcerative granulomatous disease of the skin and mucosa.

Option C: Blastomyces dermatitidis causes blastomycosis, a systemic pyogranulomatous infection involving primarily the lungs. Infection may resemble tuberculosis, or get disseminated to various parts forming multiple abscesses. A cutaneous form of the disease would present as a papule, with secondary nodules that coalesce and form ulcerative lesions.

Option D: Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis. It is an intracellular infection of the reticuloendothelial system that is acquired by inhalation. It causes a pulmonary disease similar to tuberculosis.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.
